MEDICAL. NOTICE.

Congressional Elections. The returns of the
elections for Members Of Congress were opened in
Senate, Friday last, by the Governor and Speak
er. The result, in the several districts, proved as
heretofore announced in the papers, except In the
eleventh. for which, in consequence o no return hsv-
ing been received from the county OF Holmes,
WALTER b. BEEBE was declared duly elected in
place Of JOHN c. WRIoHT. Including Holmes
county, however, i, is known that Mr.. Wright re-
ceived the highest number Of votes, and no douot,
on making this fact appear, he and not Mr.. Beebe
will be entitled to seat. Ohio Western Star.

Boring for Wyater.-1he public will be grathed
to learn. that the Messrs Pollocks have succeeded
boring for their distillery in this place.
They commenced upon rock, and proceeded to
the depth of 100 iee from the surface, from which
depth the water rises and flows al the ate OF one
and half gallons per minute. This being sufi-
cient supply the process was suspended but GER
,ainy larger supply might be obtained BY boring
deeper.


The boring was done by Mr.. Samuel Orr of this
place, who is likewise engaged in boring Tor salt
water in Buffalo Valley and has pi ioceedsd $50 feet
in depth

Every thing which we see around u.s. carries with It the
marks Of decay The seeds of dissolution sown in
cry object that the eye To-day the grass springs
forth in rich uxurance greenness on every tree heat
ty in every howeral arrayed in the oveness Of Spring
Tomorrow the winds and hosts OF Autumn take from
the grass its verdue, from the tree its reenness from the
flower its beauty, and from the Spring its lovencss. All
is now clad in the habimens of death.


The striking for it s emblem Of the life of
man To-day he stands forth in the bloom of youth, or
the strength of manhood Tomorrow some fatal disease
steals from his cheeks its beauty and from his body its
strength All his grea plans of profit or honor or plea.
sure, fled forever poor ifeess lump OF CLAY
all that remains of him, who low ely and
engaging Around his pale and emaciated body stands
the surviving friends Every heart sbg with anguish and
every eye is filled with There is not individual
present, who does not feel that there is image of him
self that after few more suns have sped their course, he
TOO must be consigned to the mansions of the dead.


All are OF the DUST and to The dust mist urn again;
and though lives should be heightened out TO three
score years and en still they will have passed


but Of this we cannot be assured We pnis siins
the Journey of fe and across path grave sunk
We may see it as approach, but backward we cannot
turn, either side we cannot pass by it, but into we
must enter. Perhaps viii be in the darkness of midnight
Then it win be hid from view shall sink, and time
with us be no longer.


When this life will end we canrn tell but be it sroner
or later STILL in the language Of scripture, it shadow,
which passeth away flower, which fadeth grass which
wthereh yapor, which dissolves in air ira sent
thought, forgotten dream; nothing IN the SIGHT OF
God. Such for shorlness our days.


Let them then be improved TO the best advantage II
we must depart to be here more and we were
into this world to prepare for anoher il this the
great business for which this life given mss it wise,
is it prudent, to defer this great till the last half
hour of existence Is then the time to prepare for
the great change which awaits when our bodies are FL


led with nsupportable ard piercing palms. when minds
are distracted with madness and filed with ,everies is
then the time examine religion, to repent OF sin. to
reform the heart to prepare for death and besides,
We know not that we shall have the least warning that
our end approaching it may come as thief in the
nghttherefore, whatsoever thy hand ndeh to do do il
with thy might for there is work, device, nor know
ledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whittier thou goest.
REFLECTIONS.

he following verses written by gentleman of Ne
* sung at the late anniversary celebration Of Il
Andrews Society Of that city.


Tune" .9d,et, a heart rarni find adieu.''
Though Scotlands hills are far away,
And ocean bows roll between,
Still, on our holy patrons day,


Fond memory shall recall the scene
Where oft our hearts, with biithesome thrill,
Responsive beat in youthful glee,
While roaming DER the heathciad hill,
Or sporting on some daisied lee:
While merry song, or legend tale,
Of days lang syne, went gaily rounds
Of the bold deeds OF plaided Gael,


Who reused him at the pibrochs souHd
And like his native mountain stream,
Rushd foamng on th' invading foe,
While his broad claymore's lightning CLEAN
Laid many saxon basnet low.
Wen call to mind those glorious days,
When the brave Wallace and the Bruces
Onward amid the battles blaze,


Bore gallantly Saint Andrews cross.
That sign 10 every Scotsman dear
Proud banner ofth mountain land,
That never wat' d DER heart of fear,
Or spread its folds in coward hand.
And Mada's plains, and Egypi's sands,
And Wateroo's sad glorious field;
Both Paynim and the Christian kinds
Know Caledona's spotess shield;
Sons of such sres, in valor bred,


And craded on the northern blast,
Far as the sun his beams hath sped,


Your fame shall sound, while time shall last.
Nor martial pride alone we claim


Science and song are both our own;
High on The roll Of letter'd fame,


Stand Scntiand's sons in bright renown,
Her daughters, too, are chaste and fair,
Adornd Nth every female grace;
And purest love, in wtching air.


Sits smiling on their blooming face.
Then aye upon Saint Andrews night,


Scotsmen! join hearts and hands as one;
Fill high the flowing goblet bright


In honor of your native home;
LIE, every cline, where'er you dwell,


From rising to the setting day,
Bear witness to your loving well


Auld Scotand's hills, though far away.

JOHN S. SKINNER, Esq


,Sir,- Some inquiries have been made oil you
observe lately, about the proper mode OF construct
ing ice houses, which have given Use TO several
communications from your correspondents on 'he
subiect.-As always feel disposed to add my mite
Of experience to the columns OF your useful Journns
will give you in as few words as possible, the con-
strucon, dimensions and cost OF an ice house which
have on my lot, the chief accommodation OF which
is its chespnrss, and the little mechanical skill me-
cesssry for its construction as mine was built en-
tireiy by the common laborers on my farm.


dug a circular pit seventeen feet deep. the di-
ameter of which is eighteen lee at the surface, and
twelve at the bottom he bottom, which was q
fine yellow sand, made to incline from he sides 10
the centre, and immediately in the centre, which
was the lowest point dug well three ieet square
and four feet deep, in order that the water might
drain off Immediately from the ice. when any thaw-
ing took place. On the bottom Of the pit over the
well, placed four large locus, sll's, and on hem
put floor of locust logs. close together as they
would lie.-l then put down logs end~se sixteen
feet six nches in length. with the small ends down.
wards, until the whole pit was lined round with
logs; at the bottom of the logs where they came in
contact with the floor. and at The top put strong
hoop. (made by splitting long viii oak saplines)
nailed every log, and two similar hoops in the IN
tcrmediae space, in order 10 keep the logs securely
in their places-on the surface over this, erected
lRnt 1907 OF Do9tU as anu iiucu u ou snS ihSidC
with corn stalks, which excellent non -conduc-
tors, and in that sheltered situation will last mary
years. consider the plan Of puttipg the logs down
endwise as much the best, because when they be-
gin to decay. il is but little trouble TO draw one out
at time and replace it with sound one whereas,


in the other plan Of building log pens, if one log
should decay near the bottom, the trouble OF re-
pairing is almost equal to building new one. In
filling my ire house, place thin cove' u green
cedar brush at the bottom, on which the ice Is
thrown and take when getting the Ice, TO have
every large piece struck with the eye OF an axe, so
as to reduce il to pieces of about pound 10 weight


place small quantity Of straw between the ice
and The wall of the house. and when foil cover the
whole with dry, clean oak leaves, which have ound
to preserve the ice much better than straw. During
the sunni er | have dry straw stuffed in between he
walls and the ice, Gas the latter recedes by melting
from the walls,) which is easily done with long
poie.-Ths ice house. which you VIII perceive IS
an inverted frustrum OF cone, contains when full,
about 1900 bushels Of ice, and although three (prl-
vste) families supplied from i constantly, it has
never given OUT

country. In 1908 Ohio was admitted State. In
1911 was the first steamboat, the Orleans launched
at Pittsburgh, on the western walers.--The state
now possesses not far from 500, 900 inhablants; now
all our nayigable streams occupied by steamboats,
now Cincinnati possesses obout 10000 inhabi
tants In the city OF Cincinnati there thirteen

Congressional Elections. The returns of the
elections for Members Of Congress were opened in
Senate, Friday last, by the Governor and Speak
er. The result, in the several districts, proved as
heretofore announced in the papers, except In the
eleventh. for which, in consequence o no return hsv-
ing been received from the county OF Holmes,
WALTER b. BEEBE was declared duly elected in
place Of JOHN c. WRIoHT. Including Holmes
county, however, i, is known that Mr.. Wright re-
ceived the highest number Of votes, and no douot,
on making this fact appear, he and not Mr.. Beebe
will be entitled to seat. Ohio Western Star.

full articles.article:
Milton, Penn December 81.
Boring for Wyater.-1he public will be grathed
to learn. that the Messrs Pollocks have succeeded
boring for their distillery in this place.
They commenced upon rock, and proceeded to
the depth of 100 iee from the surface, from which
depth the water rises and flows al the ate OF one
and half gallons per minute. This being sufi-
cient supply the process was suspended but GER
,ainy larger supply might be obtained BY boring
deeper.


The boring was done by Mr.. Samuel Orr of this
place, who is likewise engaged in boring Tor salt
water in Buffalo Valley and has pi ioceedsd $50 feet
in depth

full articles.headline: REFLECTIONS.
full articles.article:
Every thing which we see around u.s. carries with It the
marks Of decay The seeds of dissolution sown in
cry object that the eye To-day the grass springs
forth in rich uxurance greenness on every tree heat
ty in every howeral arrayed in the oveness Of Spring
Tomorrow the winds and hosts OF Autumn take from
the grass its verdue, from the tree its reenness from the
flower its beauty, and from the Spring its lovencss. All
is now clad in the habimens of death.


The striking for it s emblem Of the life of
man To-day he stands forth in the bloom of youth, or
the strength of manhood Tomorrow some fatal disease
steals from his cheeks its beauty and from his body its
strength All his grea plans of profit or honor or plea.
sure, fled forever poor ifeess lump OF CLAY
all that remains of him, who low ely and
engaging Around his pale and emaciated body stands
the surviving friends Every heart sbg with anguish and
every eye is filled with There is not individual
present, who does not feel that there is image of him
self that after few more suns have sped their course, he
TOO must be consigned to the mansions of the dead.


All are OF the DUST and to The dust mist urn again;
and though lives should be heightened out TO three
score years and en still they will have passed


but Of this we cannot be assured We pnis siins
the Journey of fe and across path grave sunk
We may see it as approach, but backward we cannot
turn, either side we cannot pass by it, but into we
must enter. Perhaps viii be in the darkness of midnight
Then it win be hid from view shall sink, and time
with us be no longer.


When this life will end we canrn tell but be it sroner
or later STILL in the language Of scripture, it shadow,
which passeth away flower, which fadeth grass which
wthereh yapor, which dissolves in air ira sent
thought, forgotten dream; nothing IN the SIGHT OF
God. Such for shorlness our days.


Let them then be improved TO the best advantage II
we must depart to be here more and we were
into this world to prepare for anoher il this the
great business for which this life given mss it wise,
is it prudent, to defer this great till the last half
hour of existence Is then the time to prepare for
the great change which awaits when our bodies are FL


led with nsupportable ard piercing palms. when minds
are distracted with madness and filed with ,everies is
then the time examine religion, to repent OF sin. to
reform the heart to prepare for death and besides,
We know not that we shall have the least warning that
our end approaching it may come as thief in the
nghttherefore, whatsoever thy hand ndeh to do do il
with thy might for there is work, device, nor know
ledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whittier thou goest.

he following verses written by gentleman of Ne
* sung at the late anniversary celebration Of Il
Andrews Society Of that city.


Tune" .9d,et, a heart rarni find adieu.''
Though Scotlands hills are far away,
And ocean bows roll between,
Still, on our holy patrons day,


Fond memory shall recall the scene
Where oft our hearts, with biithesome thrill,
Responsive beat in youthful glee,
While roaming DER the heathciad hill,
Or sporting on some daisied lee:
While merry song, or legend tale,
Of days lang syne, went gaily rounds
Of the bold deeds OF plaided Gael,


Who reused him at the pibrochs souHd
And like his native mountain stream,
Rushd foamng on th' invading foe,
While his broad claymore's lightning CLEAN
Laid many saxon basnet low.
Wen call to mind those glorious days,
When the brave Wallace and the Bruces
Onward amid the battles blaze,


Bore gallantly Saint Andrews cross.
That sign 10 every Scotsman dear
Proud banner ofth mountain land,
That never wat' d DER heart of fear,
Or spread its folds in coward hand.
And Mada's plains, and Egypi's sands,
And Wateroo's sad glorious field;
Both Paynim and the Christian kinds
Know Caledona's spotess shield;
Sons of such sres, in valor bred,


And craded on the northern blast,
Far as the sun his beams hath sped,


Your fame shall sound, while time shall last.
Nor martial pride alone we claim


Science and song are both our own;
High on The roll Of letter'd fame,


Stand Scntiand's sons in bright renown,
Her daughters, too, are chaste and fair,
Adornd Nth every female grace;
And purest love, in wtching air.


Sits smiling on their blooming face.
Then aye upon Saint Andrews night,


Scotsmen! join hearts and hands as one;
Fill high the flowing goblet bright


In honor of your native home;
LIE, every cline, where'er you dwell,


From rising to the setting day,
Bear witness to your loving well


Auld Scotand's hills, though far away.

full articles.headline:
From the american Farmer.


ICE HOUSES.
full articles.article:
JOHN S. SKINNER, Esq


,Sir,- Some inquiries have been made oil you
observe lately, about the proper mode OF construct
ing ice houses, which have given Use TO several
communications from your correspondents on 'he
subiect.-As always feel disposed to add my mite
Of experience to the columns OF your useful Journns
will give you in as few words as possible, the con-
strucon, dimensions and cost OF an ice house which
have on my lot, the chief accommodation OF which
is its chespnrss, and the little mechanical skill me-
cesssry for its construction as mine was built en-
tireiy by the common laborers on my farm.


dug a circular pit seventeen feet deep. the di-
ameter of which is eighteen lee at the surface, and
twelve at the bottom he bottom, which was q
fine yellow sand, made to incline from he sides 10
the centre, and immediately in the centre, which
was the lowest point dug well three ieet square
and four feet deep, in order that the water might
drain off Immediately from the ice. when any thaw-
ing took place. On the bottom Of the pit over the
well, placed four large locus, sll's, and on hem
put floor of locust logs. close together as they
would lie.-l then put down logs end~se sixteen
feet six nches in length. with the small ends down.
wards, until the whole pit was lined round with
logs; at the bottom of the logs where they came in
contact with the floor. and at The top put strong
hoop. (made by splitting long viii oak saplines)
nailed every log, and two similar hoops in the IN
tcrmediae space, in order 10 keep the logs securely
in their places-on the surface over this, erected
lRnt 1907 OF Do9tU as anu iiucu u ou snS ihSidC
with corn stalks, which excellent non -conduc-
tors, and in that sheltered situation will last mary
years. consider the plan Of puttipg the logs down
endwise as much the best, because when they be-
gin to decay. il is but little trouble TO draw one out
at time and replace it with sound one whereas,


in the other plan Of building log pens, if one log
should decay near the bottom, the trouble OF re-
pairing is almost equal to building new one. In
filling my ire house, place thin cove' u green
cedar brush at the bottom, on which the ice Is
thrown and take when getting the Ice, TO have
every large piece struck with the eye OF an axe, so
as to reduce il to pieces of about pound 10 weight


place small quantity Of straw between the ice
and The wall of the house. and when foil cover the
whole with dry, clean oak leaves, which have ound
to preserve the ice much better than straw. During
the sunni er | have dry straw stuffed in between he
walls and the ice, Gas the latter recedes by melting
from the walls,) which is easily done with long
poie.-Ths ice house. which you VIII perceive IS
an inverted frustrum OF cone, contains when full,
about 1900 bushels Of ice, and although three (prl-
vste) families supplied from i constantly, it has
never given OUT

full articles.article:
CLNCIN.N:qTI-A1 1889 this place was a
wilderness, and in that year the First survey OF
this city by Israel Ludlow. In 1889 was the first
Judicial court organized at Cincinnati, in the Miami


country. In 1908 Ohio was admitted State. In
1911 was the first steamboat, the Orleans launched
at Pittsburgh, on the western walers.--The state
now possesses not far from 500, 900 inhablants; now
all our nayigable streams occupied by steamboats,
now Cincinnati possesses obout 10000 inhabi
tants In the city OF Cincinnati there thirteen

In the construction Of ice houses. /, is great
convenience TO have The door made sufficiently wide
TO receive with ease, the tail OF the cart or Wagon
within il, in unloading, as il can be done in hall the
time. All ice houses should have window in the
upper part of he gable end with shutter to IT, as
it is absolutely necessary IN very hot weather, TO
sentila,e them In the estimate above, have cal
cuated all the expense that farmer could possibly
incur in building an ice house OF the kind recon-
mended; bot mine done a, a very leisure time,
and therefore did not luay all the expense
stated.


Yours, respectfully, u.
